awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Enabling Adaptable, Object Oriented, Real-time Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The increasing need for real-time guarantees in mobile embedded systems poses a unique set of challenges, including changing software, just-in-time (JIT) compilation, and dynamic interactions between applications of differing criticality levels.  This project develops techniques to provide adaptability to software systems that require stringent correctness and timing guarantees. The novelty of this work is in the development of new techniques to ensure the correctness and timeliness of adaptive software, new programming models to ease the development burden of adaptive software,  and the development of an execution platform for adaptive software. The impacts of this work will be felt by providing predictable execution in mobile applications for sensing, personalized health care, command and control, and automotive domains, as well as providing professional development on the topic of mobile programming to teachers in the Buffalo Public School district.  Additionally, this award supports the training of Ph.D. students and integration of research into educational materials.

This project investigates language level, compiler, and run-time techniques that enable the construction of adaptive real-time systems.  The project develops a novel, partitioned run-time, including support for executing multiple real-time and non real-time applications, cross application communication abstractions with concrete predictability guarantees, as well as  partitioned virtual machine-level services, such as JIT compilation and garbage collection. The run-time is expressive enough to support Android's APIs and execution model, yet affords predictability guarantees necessary for real-time support.  Furthermore, the project develops a series of validation mechanisms that ensure real-time guarantees for mobile systems, and constructs a programming model that expresses adaptability in real-time systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under this award the principal investigator developed new language based techniques for developing safe, reliable, and adaptable mobile, embedded, and Internet of things systems. All of these domains share a common requirement that for correctness a system needs not only to be functionally correct but must also adhere to system specific timing constraints. Additionally, communication between components, processes, and programs in these systems is often specified through communication protocols. Crucially, providing higher level mechanisms for programmers who develop software systems in these domains provides greater fidelity that the software systems and communication protocols that govern their interactions are correct.

The principal investigator has explored language design and language runtime design that are timing aware in the context of object oriented, functional, and imperative languages. This resulted in the development of a real-time mobile framework for time constrained, adaptable Android applications for smart devices; the creation of a Standard ML compiler, message passing language, and language runtime for developing real-time functional programs; and a Rust crate for validating message passing protocols in an imperative language. The languages developed under this award are capable of providing high-level guarantees on timing, memory usage, isolation of components, and communication. For instance, the Standard ML garbage collector developed under this award provides tighter memory guarantees through timing aware packing of objects at runtime. Many of the systems in this award’s target domains are fundamentally message-passing systems, using the exchange of messages through send and receive primitives as the core communication mechanisms between components and programs. The principal investigator developed a new, priority aware, higher order message passing language on top of Concurrent ML (CML). Specifically the addition of priorities to the event combinators provided by CML allows for more robust communication primitives that are timing aware. The principal investigator also developed a new session type system for periodic communicating processes, able to validate timing correctness of communication protocols by type checking as well as an event based model for session types able to express failure handling in systems which can exhibit transient faults. Validation of the technical developments made under this award were conducted on real-world systems and benchmarks derived from real-world systems, including in part unmanned aerial vehicles, sound processing on mobile devices for cochlear implants, software defined sensors on mobile phones, key-less entry systems in cars, and smart watch heart rate sensors. The technical developments under this award have resulted in twenty two peer reviewed artifacts and four Ph.D. theses. A fifth Ph.D. thesis is expected to be defended in the near future. 

The project in total has provided professional development opportunities for six Ph.D. students, eight masters students, and twelve undergraduate students. During the award period the principal investigator has provided in-class educational opportunities for both undergraduate and masters students leveraging the frameworks, methodologies, and theoretical innovations developed in the context of this award. The technology developed under this award has been incorporated into the programming languages courses offered at the University at Buffalo and has resulted in two multi-semester projects in the Experiential Learning and Research track offered for undergraduate students.
